article.headline: Oklahoma State 73, Arkansas 58
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Eddie Sutton went 121-8 in Fayetteville when he coached at Arkansas from 1974-85, but all those games were in the old Barnhill Arena. He had never coached in Bud Walton Arena, the 19,200-seat palace he helped raise money to build by winning 260 games and making basketball popular in Arkansas. Sutton now has 300 wins at Oklahoma State and he's 1-0 at Bud Walton after his Cowboys breezed to a 73-58 victory over Arkansas on Saturday. Tony Allen didn't start in Oklahoma State's previous game, but he scored 22 points and grabbed 10 rebounds to make Sutton's return victorious. "It was a little eerie when the fans started calling the Hogs and the band played the fight song," said Sutton, who guided the Razorbacks to the 1978 Final Four. "It brought back a lot of wonderful memories from my 11 years here in Arkansas. "It was a little different being on the sideline and seeing that big old Razorback on the floor and you knew we're going to try to beat the Hogs." Oklahoma State (6-1) broke open a close game by holding Arkansas (6-2) without a field goal for a 10-minute stretch that started in the first half and extended four minutes into the second. The Cowboys put together a 21-5 run in between baskets by Arkansas freshman Ronnie Brewer. "I thought we had some really good looks at the basket, some layups, some open shots and some free throws," Arkansas coach Stan Heath said. "We just didn't put ourselves in position to win a game like this. As I told our team, those are plays that we have to make." Oklahoma State extended its lead to 49-32 before the Razorbacks cut it to 52-43 with 7 minutes left in the game. Wen Mukubu came off the bench for a basket and leading scorer Jonathon Modica came to life with seven points in the run. "I'm tired of playing hard and losing," Modica said. "We need to start winning these games." Modica came in averaging 21 points per game, but had just two in the first half. He battled back to score 23 and Brewer finished with 15 points. "We wanted to try to keep the ball away from (Modica)," Sutton said. "I think he's a slasher and a driver, so once he caught it, we tried to step back on him and help when he drove. We didn't do a very good job of that in the second half." Joey Graham, who added 13 points, returned the momentum to Oklahoma State with a 3-pointer at the 5:38 mark to push Oklahoma State's lead back to 57-43. Point guard John Lucas finished with 14 points for the Cowboys and Ivan McFarlin had 13 points and 13 rebounds. "As a team, we wanted to win this game for coach Sutton," McFarlin said. Arkansas came out cold and shot 35 percent for the game, 29.2 in the first half, and Oklahoma State made it hard for the Razorbacks to get close to the basket. Arkansas' players didn't help themselves at the free- throw line either, making just 12 of 23 shots. Arkansas led briefly in the first half when Brewer gave Arkansas a 17-15 edge with 6:14 left in the half with a dunk after a backdoor pass from Rashard Sullivan. But Oklahoma State finished the half with a 12-1 run, capped by John Lucas' halfcourt shot at the buzzer. The junior grabbed a long rebound after Billy Pharis missed a 3-pointer and his shot gave the Cowboys a 27-18 lead at intermission. "I just threw it up there," Lucas said. "I saw it was on line, but I thought I threw it too hard. Coming into halftime with a nine-point lead is a lot different than a six-point lead. That shifted the momentum back." Heath said the shot epitomized the way Arkansas ended the half, missing its final five shots and making one free throw in four attempts. "It wasn't devastating, but it was a momentum play," he said. "It's like, 'Gosh, what else can go wrong?' "That was three we don't get and three they get. It's a six-point turnaround just like that. That's what I mean. There was a lot of breaks that went their way. I guess it was Eddie's homecoming party." This was Sutton's first game in Fayetteville since 1985, when he coached Arkansas to a 106-71 victory over Baylor, and he received a hearty round of applause from the crowd at Bud Walton Arena. This was the final game in a four-year series and Sutton won all four against his former school. Sutton said he hoped the two schools could continue the series if Heath was willing to extend it. Arkansas' home game against the Cowboys in 2001 was played in North Little Rock. Returning this year's game to Fayetteville helped draw 18,917 fans, the largest crowd in Heath's two seasons with the Razorbacks.
